head.title: Selectivity Modulated by Surface Ligands on Cu2O/TiO2 Catalysts for Gas-Phase Photocatalytic Reduction of Carbon Dioxide | The Journal of Physical Chemistry C

meta.content: Selectivity Modulated by Surface Ligands on Cu2O/TiO2 Catalysts for Gas-Phase Photocatalytic Reduction of Carbon Dioxide

We report gas-phase photocatalytic CO2 reduction with Cu2O/TiO2 photocatalysts of varying surface passivation. With taurine adsorbed on the photocatalyst surface, the CH4 production rate increases and CO production rate decreases compared to photocatalysts with no ligand treatment. When ethylenediamine is present on Cu2O/TiO2 photocatalysts, CO selectivity enhances significantly. In situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and density functional theory calculation reveal that the surface ligands on the photocatalyst surface alter the binding strength of reaction intermediates (e.g., CO) on surface atoms of the photocatalysts. Our findings cast light on a new design principle for the catalyst surface in selective CO2 conversion.

div.span: Supporting Info (1)
SUBJECTS:

a.title: Go to The Journal of Physical Chemistry C

img.alt: Go to The Journal of Physical Chemistry C

div.p:
We report gas-phase photocatalytic CO
2
reduction with Cu
2
O/TiO
2
photocatalysts of varying surface passivation. With taurine adsorbed on the photocatalyst surface, the CH
4
production rate increases and CO production rate decreases compared to photocatalysts with no ligand treatment. When ethylenediamine is present on Cu
2
O/TiO
2
photocatalysts, CO selectivity enhances significantly. In situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and density functional theory calculation reveal that the surface ligands on the photocatalyst surface alter the binding strength of reaction intermediates (e.g., CO) on surface atoms of the photocatalysts. Our findings cast light on a new design principle for the catalyst surface in selective CO
2
conversion.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The impetus for the study of chemical conversion of CO
2
via catalytic reactions has resulted from the pressing need to mitigate the ever-increasing concentration of CO
2
in the atmosphere.
(1−5)
With the controversy over the global warming issue still in the balance, the recent abrupt increase in CO
2
concentration elicits a surge of motive for the reuse of CO
2
as a chemical feedstock.
(6)
Several CO
2
conversion approaches based on the catalytic reaction have proven successful, and it has been found that lowering the energy barrier for the reaction intermediates is the key to enhancing the conversion yield.
(7−9)
The binding energy of the intermediate species to the catalytic surface has a strong correlation with catalytic activity and product selectivity.
(10)
Notably, in electrocatalytic CO
2
conversion, the binding strength of CO as a reaction intermediate to the catalyst surface plays an instrumental role in product selectivity: for example, Au, Ag, and Zn, which have weak CO binding energy, tend to produce CO as a final product, while in the case of Cu, which binds CO strongly, more electrochemically reduced products such as methanol or methane are favored.
(11−13)
Also, in photocatalytic CO
2
conversion based on Cu photocatalysts, it has been reported that changes of catalyst surface composition and CO binding energy relate to the reaction selectivity.

Surface modification of photocatalysts using various ligand species is a promising way to control the selectivity of photochemical CO
2
conversion.
(20,21,34−36)
For instance, the hydrogen evolution reaction can be suppressed by decreased H
2
O adsorption after the catalyst surface is modified to be hydrophobic, resulting in increased CO
2
conversion selectivity.
(22)
In another study, fluorinated polymer surrounding photocatalyst particles helps to capture reaction intermediates of CO
2
-to-hydrocarbon conversion, eventually increasing the selectivity of a target hydrocarbon product.
(23)
Although these studies have provided insightful observations, the study on the effect of surface ligand molecules on the change of CO binding strength is relatively lacking, particularly in the context of selectivity of CO
2
-to-hydrocarbon conversion. As mentioned above, because CO is the critical reaction intermediate in the CO
2
conversion process, it is very crucial to understand how surface modification affects the CO binding strength to control the product selectivity.

In this study, we prepare Cu
2
O/TiO
2
heterostructured photocatalysts with ligand molecules bound to the surface and examine the selectivity of photocatalytic CO
2
conversion using the photocatalyst heterostructures. In detail, we employed subnanoscale Cu
2
O particles as cocatalysts, at which photoexcited electrons reside because of the Z-scheme formation and the photocatalytic CO
2
reduction occurs.
(30−32)
Molecules such as taurine (TAU) and ethylenediamine (EDA) are used to modify the surface of bare photocatalysts. We carry out Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, Auger spectroscopy, and first-principle calculation studies to elucidate the reaction mechanism of CO
2
conversion in the presence of different ligand molecules on the catalyst surface. The experimental and theoretical characterizations and photocatalysis results allow us to quantitatively analyze the correlation between the CO binding strength and product selectivity in CO
2
conversion.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The photocatalysts were prepared via a recipe described in a previous study.
(17)
Figure
1
shows that productivity and selectivity of CO
2
photoreduction change dramatically depending on the ligand treatment. In the case of bare Cu
2
O/TiO
2
photocatalysts, 24 μmol·g
–1
·h
–1
of CO was produced as a major product similarly to previous studies.
(14−16)
Note that the bare TiO
2
catalysts without Cu
2
O show low performance for photocatalytic CO
2
reduction and unchanged selectivity compared with each ligand-assisted bare TiO
2
samples (
Figure S9
). This result indicates that the modulated selectivity of ligand-assisted Cu
2
O/TiO
2
is mainly induced by the interaction of ligand–Cu
2
O, not by TiO
2
–ligand or ligand–water interaction. Considering the number of electrons in reactions, for example, two for CO
2
-to-CO and eight for CO
2
-to-CH
4
, ligand-treated samples (*TAU and *EDA) show the increased overall photocatalytic activity. On the other hand, the product selectivity between CH
4
and CO greatly differs from the case of the bare photocatalyst. As shown in
Figure
1
b, *TAU can generate 2.4 times more CH
4
and 3.3 times less CO than the bare sample, whereas in the case of *EDA, the CO productivity increases by more than 2.0 times and CH
4
is produced in an even lesser quantity than the bare case. Interestingly, the reaction tendency in the *TAU system is further enhanced when excess TAU ligands are adsorbed on the photocatalyst surface (*TAU-ex). The rate of CH
4
generation increased from 3.73 to 7.86 μmol·g
–1
·h
–1
and the rate of CO generation decreased dramatically from 7.21 to 2.97 μmol·g
–1
·h
–1
between *TAU and *TAU-ex. TEM images in
Figure
1
c–e show Cu
2
O cocatalysts deposited on the surface of the TiO
2
nanoparticles (<100 nm) to the size of <1 nm. Elemental mapping images also support Cu element existence on the surfaces (
Figure
1
f–h).

div.p:
Figure 1. (a) Amounts of CO and CH
4
formed during the photocatalytic reduction of CO
2
. Reaction conditions: catalyst, 0.4 mg; CO
2
pressure, 101.3 kPa; and irradiation time, 4 h. (b) Averaged generation rates of CO and CH
4
in the first 4 h of the photocatalysis. (c–e) Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of *TAU. Orange arrows: Cu
2
O nanoparticles. (f–h) Elemental mapping of Cu
2
O/TiO
2
.

div.div:
To confirm the origin of carbon-based products and the stability of our catalyst system, we performed a series of controlled photocatalytic experiments and spectroscopic analyses. The trend in the overall activity and selectivity does not change during the additional cycles of the reaction, confirming that the adsorbed ligand molecules do not detach or decompose on the Cu
2
O catalyst during the reaction (
Figure
2
a). We prove that the CH
4
product directly comes from CO
2
gas in the reactor, from the linear dependency between the CH
4
generation rate and the CO
2
concentration in the photocatalytic reaction test depending on the CO
2
concentration (
Figure S2
). In addition, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and X-ray fluorescence (XRF) characterizations show that the oxidation state of Cu and adsorbed TAU ligand molecules is maintained after the photocatalytic reaction (
Figures
2
b–d and
S14
, and
Table S2
).
(24,25)
XPS spectra reveal the Cu oxidation state of catalysts before and after CO
2
reduction reaction (
Figure
2
g–h). XPS spectra show that Cu(I) oxide, Cu metal, and Cu(II) oxide peaks are observed with increasing intensity in order, and the intensity ratio of peaks is maintained before and after the postligand treatment process [Cu(I) oxide peak for 932.18 eV; Cu metal peak for 932.63 eV; Cu(II) oxide peak for 933.76 eV].
(40)
This result supports that postligand treatments do not influence on the chemical structure of Cu particles. Also, each Cu peak intensity ratio is not changed before and after the photocatalytic reaction. These results highly support that Cu oxidation states are barely unchanged after the photocatalytic reaction condition and the Cu(I) oxide state acts as a cocatalyst for photocatalytic CO
2
reduction. XRF data and control experiments show that the ligand molecules are neither converted to gas products after the reaction nor degraded during the reaction (
Table S2
,
Figures S3 and S10
). From the CO
2
chemisorption measurements, the number of effective active sites of the Cu
2
O catalysts is reduced by the ligand adsorption, which means that the activity of the unit active site is definitely enhanced by the ligand (
Figure S12
). Therefore, from these systematic changes of activity and selectivity of CO
2
conversion depending on the type and concentration of the ligand, we speculate that the interaction between reaction intermediates and the photocatalyst surface has been modulated by the adsorbed ligand.

div.p:
Figure 2. (a) Multirun photocatalysis results. CO
2
gas was bubbled into water for 1 h before being fed into the reactor vessel between each cycle in dark conditions. (b–d) Cu 2p XPS spectra of Cu
2
O/TiO
2
, *TAU, and *EDA before and after CO
2
reduction experiments. (e) Auger spectra of Cu
2
O/TiO
2
catalysts.

div.div:
We perform the in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) measurement to analyze the interaction between the active site on the catalyst surface and the initial reactant, CO
2
, under photoillumination conditions.
Figure
3
shows the analysis results for bare, *TAU, and *EDA samples under CO
2
flow (without H
2
O) and irradiation conditions. Species of carboxylate CO
2
–
(CO
2
–
at 1666 and 1248 cm
–1
), monodentate carbonate (m-CO
3
2–
at 1557 and 1480 cm
–1
), bidentate carbonate (b-CO
3
2–
at 1595 and 1303 cm
–1
), polydentate carbonate (p-CO
3
2–
at 1372 cm
–1
) peaks are shown in DRIFTS spectra of irradiated samples.
(18,24,25,37)
We attribute dramatic changes of the absorption spectra at an early stage (<15 min) to electron transfers from the photocatalyst to adsorbed CO
2
. However, after 15 min, the bands of intermediate states undergo relatively marginal changes as further conversion is suppressed in the anhydrous environment. As shown in
Figure
3
a, the bare sample shows strongly adsorbed CO
2
–
carboxylate bands in the initial condition, which constitute major spectral features on the Cu
2
O/TiO
2
-based photocatalyst surface in CO
2
conditions.
(18,24,37)
Upon photoillumination, the CO
2
–
bands decrease dramatically. Prolonging the illumination time to 120 min resulted in the disappearance of CO
2
–
, but an increase in the intensity of bands from the m-CO
3
2–
.
(24,25)
This result suggests that CO
2
may be strongly adsorbed on the catalyst surface at the initial stage as a reduced form of CO
2
–
, and illumination turns CO
2
–
into a more reduced form of m-CO
3
2–
. Because these CO
2
–
and m-CO
3
2–
species are not stable, they would be immediately converted into CO and CH
4
in the real reaction environment having proton sources.
(14,27)
(
Table
1
).

div.p:
Figure 3. In situ DRIFTS analysis of (a) bare Cu
2
O/TiO
2
, (b) Cu
2
O/TiO
2
with TAU (*TAU), and (c) Cu
2
O/TiO
2
with EDA (*EDA).

div.div: Table 1. Spectral Assignment for in Situ DRIFTS Spectra

Interestingly, spectral features from *TAU and *EDA samples differ significantly under the illumination conditions. As shown in
Figure
3
b, both CO
2
–
and b-CO
3
2–
are observed at the initial condition in the *TAU system.
(24,27)
These species are converted into p-CO
3
2–
after 15 min of photoillumination.
(25)
These observed bidentate and polydentate carbonate species in TAU conditions indicate stronger binding between the reaction intermediates and catalyst surface. Many articles report that strong interaction with an intermediate of CO
2
reduction reaction induces further reducing reaction.
(11,38,39)
Therefore, enhanced binding between the *TAU catalyst surface and intermediate species is likely to produce a larger quantity of further reduced chemicals (e.g., CH
4
). We will discuss intermediate binding in more detail in the simulation part. In addition, the m-CO
3
2–
band was also detected in *TAU, indicating that the overarching nature of CO
2
bonding on the surface bears similarity between *TAU and bare catalyst systems.

Unlike *TAU, only CO
2
–
bands are observed in the case of *EDA at the initial stage (
Figure
3
c), and other intermediate states such as monodentate and bidentate carbonate peaks are not observed in the DRIFT spectra. This change in spectral features upon illumination in the *EDA case alludes to a weaker binding between the reaction intermediates and catalyst surface, which could be responsible for enhanced CO generation compared to the bare system. In addition, the gas-phase CO derived from a partially completed reaction was detected only in the *EDA system (2175 cm
–1
in
Figure
3
c), whereas the rest of the cases show stable Cu–CO interactions at 2112 cm
–1
(
Figure
3
a,b).
(26)
The DRIFTS analysis explains the CO
2
photoreduction results, in which *TAU tends to generate more CH
4
while *EDA, more CO.

To provide the detailed mechanism of the changes in the photochemical CO
2
conversion depending on the type of the ligand adsorbed on the catalysts, we perform density functional theory (DFT) simulations. Based on the role of binding strength of CO on the catalyst surface to selectivity of CO
2
conversion, we speculate that the increase in CH
4
production by TAU and the increase in CO production by EDA are likely because of the changes of the interaction strength between CO and the catalyst surface by adsorbed ligands. To confirm this speculation, we calculated binding energies of key reaction intermediates, such as −COOH and CO, on the catalyst surface. Note that the binding of ligand molecules slightly changes the initial adsorption behavior of CO
2
in terms of the binding energy and structure.
(33)
However, we do not consider this effect in the interpretation of CO
2
photoreduction performance because the key reaction intermediate, −COOH, has a more significant binding strength than CO
2
on the catalyst surface, as shown later (
Figure S13
). The atomic model representing a subnanosized Cu
2
O cocatalyst (bare photocatalyst) was generated using a Monte Carlo technique based on the reactive force field (ReaxFF) potential energy.
(26)
(
Figure
4
a, see details in the
Supporting Information
.)

div.p:
Figure 4. (a) Atomic structure of the subnanosized Cu
2
O photocatalyst (Cu
22
O
12
) and those with two different ligands adsorbed (*TAU and *EDA). The most active Cu site is located at the long side of the catalyst edge. (b) 2D color map showing the theoretical reduction potential of CO
2
-to-CO conversion as a function of the binding free energies of −COOH and CO on the catalyst surface obtained from ref
(27)
. Calculated −COOH and CO binding energies on the bare catalyst (Cu
22
O
12
, violet); *TAU (blue) and *EDA (red) are shown on the color map.

div.div:
As suggested in a previous theoretical study, the process of forming the −COOH intermediate by the first proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) into CO
2
is very costly, so the catalytic activity basically depends on how much the catalyst can stabilize the −COOH intermediate.
(27)
The binding energies of −COOH and CO onto the bare Cu
2
O cocatalyst calculated by DFT simulations are −1.42 and −0.65 eV, respectively, on the Cu atom at the long side (active site in
Figure
4
a, a more negative value means a stronger binding), which is positioned on the linear scaling relation trend established for the pure metal slab surfaces (black squares in
Figure
4
b). The fact that the binding energy of CO is in the proximity of the intermediate regime (ca. −0.5 eV) corroborates an experimental observation that both CO and CH
4
are produced in the bare photocatalyst system.

Next, we examined the effect of ligands on the −COOH and CO binding energies. The most stable adsorption sites and configurations were determined using structures optimized from the series of DFT calculations; the TAU ligand is bound to two edge Cu and one corner O sites as a zwitterionic form with −1.49 eV binding energy, and the EDA ligand is bound to one long-edge Cu site in a cis-form with −1.39 eV binding energy (
Figure
4
a). DFT results find that the presence of the TAU ligand enhances −COOH and CO binding free energies as −1.54 and −0.83 eV, respectively (blue circle in
Figure
4
b). Interestingly, for the EDA ligand, the binding strength of −COOH is enhanced to −1.53 eV, but the binding strength of CO is lowered to −0.30 eV (red circle in
Figure
4
b). In both cases, the overall increases in experimental catalytic activity can be explained by the reduction of the thermodynamic barrier of the first PCET process by the enhanced binding strength of −COOH. On the other hand, resulting from the opposite changes of the binding strength of CO depending on the ligand, further reduction proceeds in the *TAU case to produce more CH
4
, and CO desorption is more facilitated in the EDA case.

We further examine the origin of the distinct ligand effect on CO binding. As shown in
Figure S7
, we find that the Cu–O antibonding orbital character of the Cu active site contributes to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of the bare catalyst. In the case of *EDA, the contribution from the Cu–O antibonding orbital character to the LUMO is suppressed, while still a similar contribution is found for the *TAU case. Considering the CO binding process as an electron lone-pair donation to the LUMO state, the CO binding is thus expected to weaken the Cu–O bonding. Indeed, from the DFT-optimized structures, the linear O–Cu–O angle is changed into 108.8° after the CO binding, which is substantially suppressed for the *EDA case (∠O–Cu–O = 161.9°) but slightly enhanced for the *TAU case (∠O–Cu–O = 98.3°). Our conjecture is that the weakened Cu–O bonding leads to a protrusion of the Cu active site and thereby enables a strengthened Cu–CO bond, which is the *TAU case, and the opposite transpires for the *EDA case.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In summary, we successfully controlled the performance of CO
2
conversion based on the Cu
2
O/TiO
2
photocatalysts. The TAU treatment enhances the CH
4
selectivity, whereas the EDA treatment facilitates the CO selectivity compared to the bare catalyst. The experimental in situ DRIFTS measurements and the first-principle DFT calculations reveal that adsorbed ligands alter the binding strength of −COOH and CO on the catalyst surface, ultimately responsible for the significant swing of product selectivity despite the use of the same Cu
2
O/TiO
2
photocatalysts. We expect this study to provide a reliable strategy to modulate the selectivity of the photocatalytic CO
2
conversion based on the ligand treatment approach.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
All FT-IR spectra presented in this work were recorded on a Nicolet 6700 spectrometer (Thermo Electron) equipped with a liquid-nitrogen-cooled HgCdTe (MCT) detector. The spectra were displayed in absorbance units, and acquired with a resolution of 4 cm
–1
, using 32 scans. The in situ DRIFTS studies were performed in a Praying Mantis DRIFTS accessory and a reaction chamber (Harrick Scientific, HVC-DRP). The dome of the cell has one KBr window allowing IR transmission and a window allowing transmission of irradiation introduced through a liquid light guide (Newport) that connects to a 450 W Xe arc system (Oriel).

Cu(NO
3
)
2
·3H
2
O, TAU, and EDA were purchased from Aldrich. TiO
2
(P25), which contained 20% rutile and 80% anatase, was purchased from Degussa. Cu
2
O/TiO
2
samples were prepared following a previous study. Briefly, TiO
2
(1 g) was suspended in a solution of Cu(NO
3
)
2
·3H
2
O (38 mg) in 50 mL of deionized water for 1 wt % Cu
2
O/TiO
2
. The solution was kept at 343 K and was stirred for 24 h. The resulting blue powder was calcined under a H
2
flow at 823 K for 5 h. After exposure to air, the Cu nanoparticle was oxidized as Cu
2
O immediately. For TAU ligand attachment, Cu
2
O/TiO
2
(0.1 mg) and TAU (0.08 mmol) were mixed in 50 mL of deionized water for 24 h. Then, the sample was filtered by using a vacuum filter for removing unattached ligands. The powder was dried at 343 K in an oven. Cu
2
O/TiO
2
with the EDA photocatalyst is formed by the same method. We used high-resolution TEM and XPS to analyze the structure and composition of Cu
2
O/TiO
2
photocatalysts. The Cu
2
O cocatalysts deposited on the surface of the TiO
2
nanoparticles (<100 nm) to the size of <1 nm (
Figure
2
). The Auger LMM line of Cu
+
appears at 570.2 eV, indicative of the formation of Cu
2
O in
Figure
2
j. To control the CO binding energy of the Cu
2
O surface, we adopted TAU and EDA ligands. The crystallinity and size of Cu
2
O cocatalysts did not significantly change after the ligand treatment. The composition estimated from the XRF spectra listed in
Table S1
clearly suggests that the different amounts of the TAU ligand passivated on samples depend on different concentrations. To increase the injection volume of TAU (10 times), the composition of sulfur was increased from 0.0012 to 0.0819 at the same amount of Cu
2
O/TiO
2
. We denote the sample with 0.0012 sulfur-treated TAU as *TAU and a sample with 0.0819 sulfur-treated TAU as *TAU-ex. For the *TAU sample, 0.07 TAU ligands are passivated on each Cu
2
O cocatalyst surface and 6 ligands are passivated on each Cu
2
O cocatalyst in the *TAU-ex sample. We also denote that the EDA-treated Cu
2
O/TiO
2
sample is *EDA. The nanoparticles were characterized by XPS, TEM, and CO
2
chemisorption measurements. TEM measurements were performed with a JEM-ARM200F electron microscope (JEOL) operated at an acceleration voltage of 300 kV. XPS measurements were performed with a Sigma Probe (Thermo VG Scientific). The amount of CO
2
chemisorbed was measured with a 3 Flex (Micromeritics) apparatus. The adsorption isotherm of CO
2
was measured after a pretreatment step at 473 K under N
2
gas. After that, CO
2
was adsorbed on samples at room temperature. This adsorption isotherm was expressed as a function of the Langmuir adsorption isotherm.

div.h3:
In Situ DRIFTS Analysis for CO
2
Photoreduction
div.div:
In situ DRIFTS spectra of CO
2
photoreduction were recorded for bare Cu
2
O/TiO
2
and ligand-treated Cu
2
O/TiO
2
. In the cases of bare Cu
2
O/TiO
2
, Cu
2
O/TiO
2
with TAU (*TAU), and Cu
2
O/TiO
2
with EDA (*EDA), each sample was purged with N
2
for 30 min at 25 °C, and a background spectrum in the presence of the sample was collected. After that, 10% CO
2
/Ar was continuously passed into the chamber at 30 mL/min for 30 min. Subsequently, the inlet and outlet valves of the DRIFTS reaction cell were closed, and the sample was subjected to photoillumination for 120 min. In the cases of the ligand-treated photocatalyst, the same procedure was used to obtain the IR spectra except that the sample underwent the previously described N
2
-pretreatment process at 100 °C and the DRIFTS reaction cell was allowed to cool down to 25 °C before the IR spectra were taken for removal of the carbon source on the surface.

Photocatalytic reactions were performed with 0.4 mg of the catalyst under CO
2
gas with water vapor.
(19,29,32)
The CO
2
gas purged through DI water solution, so the H source came from the vapor in the CO
2
gas. The light source was a 300 W Xe lamp in the ultraviolet–visible region(λ = 320–780 nm) (
Figure S2
). The photocatalytic reactions were performed at room temperature for 4 h at atmospheric pressure. Note that no H
2
generation was detected in all the samples in our experimental conditions. These phenomena may be induced by low water concentration compared with CO
2
, as water is the reactant molecule for H
2
generation reaction.
(19,29,32)
The amount of CO and CH
4
was analyzed by gas chromatography. We used a flame-ionization detector (FID) to quantify the amounts of products generated from CO
2
. H
2
, CH
4
, and CO were the major products that have been observed in the work in all of the experiments. As shown in
Figure
1
a, the selectivity of CO
2
photoconversion is dramatically changed depending on the ligand treatment, and it also shows that the linearity in the H
2
, CH
4
, and CO production indicates the good stability of photocatalytic systems. By measuring the concentrations of CO and CH
4
at the reactor outlet, the production of CO and CH
4
, in μmolg
–1
, during a 4 h photoillumination period was calculated. The amounts of CO and CH
4
after the reaction were analyzed by gas chromatography. We adopted the FID to quantify the amount of products formed from CO
2
to ensure high sensitivities. CO and CO
2
were converted into CH
4
in the methanation reactor and were analyzed by the FID. Ar was used as the carrier gas. The detection limits of our gas chromatography for CH
4
and CO were both 6 nmol. H
2
was monitored by using a thermal conductivity detector. Photocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction under visible light irradiation was conducted with Cu
2
O/TiO
2
particles (
Figure S11
). As TiO
2
cannot absorb in the visible light region, only Cu
2
O particles have the photocatalytic activity in visible light irradiation. This result supports that the photocatalytic CO
2
reduction reaction works with the Cu
2
O cocatalyst.

To build the reasonable atomic model for subnanoscale Cu and Cu
2
O particles, we employed Monte Carlo simulations based on the Metropolis algorithm using the ReaxFF potential, which parameterized for the Cu/O/H system.
(26)
After obtaining the stable structure of the copper oxide particle as Cu
22
O
12
, DFT calculations for evaluating binding energies of the reactant, reaction intermediates, and ligands were performed using Jaguar 8.9 software.
(28)
We used the exchange–correlation functional of B3LYP along with the LACVP** basis set. We explicitly assigned the singlet spin state for the Cu
2
O cluster model based on the experimental observations that there is no magnetic property in our Cu
2
O/TiO
2
catalyst particles in
Figure S8
. Moreover, only doublet spin states were assigned when the reaction intermediate −COOH is adsorbed. The geometries for the bare catalyst and those with adsorbed reaction intermediates such as −COOH and CO were fully minimized within convergence criteria as 5.0 × 10
–7
Ha. To transform the gas-phase binding energy to aqueous binding free energy, we adopted the previously reported linear correlations for various metal surfaces (Δ
G
B,COOH
= 0.7444·Δ
E
B,COOH
—0.2679; Δ
G
B,CO
= 0.9959·Δ
E
B,CO
—0.0183; unit: eV).
(27)

A review. Two major energy-related problems confront the world in the next 50 years. First, increased worldwide competition for gradually depleting fossil fuel reserves (derived from past photosynthesis) will lead to higher costs, both monetarily and politically. Second, atm. CO2 levels are at their highest recorded level since records began. Further increases are predicted to produce large and uncontrollable impacts on the world climate. These projected impacts extend beyond climate to ocean acidification, because the ocean is a major sink for atm. CO2. Providing a future energy supply that is secure and CO2-neutral will require switching to non-fossil energy sources such as wind, solar, nuclear, and geothermal energy and developing methods for transforming the energy produced by these new sources into forms that can be stored,transported, and used upon demand. This Review describes the results of a workshop held to explore these concepts in regard to the development of new and more efficient catalytic processes for the conversion of CO2 to a variety of carbon-based fuels.

A review. Photocatalytic conversion of CO2 to either a renewable fuel or valuable chems., using solar energy has attracted more and more attention, due to the great potential to provide an alternative clean fuel and solve the problems related to the global warming. This review covers the current progress of photocatalytic conversion of CO2 by photocatalysis over the metal oxides. A brief overview of the fundamental aspects for artificial photosynthesis has been given and the development of novel photocatalysts for CO2 photoredn. has been discussed. Several key factors for high-efficiency CO2 photoredn. and the recent development of photocatalytic reactor design for this artificial photosynthesis have also been highlighted.

A review. Photocatalytic redn. of CO2 into hydrocarbon fuels, an artificial photosynthesis, is based on the simulation of natural photosynthesis in green plants, whereby O2 and carbohydrates are produced from H2O and CO2 using sunlight as an energy source. It couples the reductive half-reaction of CO2 fixation with a matched oxidative half-reaction such as H2O oxidn., to achieve a C neutral cycle, which is like killing 2 birds with one stone in terms of saving the environment and supplying future energy. The present review provides an overview and highlights recent state-of-the-art accomplishments of overcoming the drawback of low photoconversion efficiency and selectivity through the design of highly active photocatalysts from the point of adsorption of reactants, charge sepn. and transport, light harvesting, and CO2 activation. It specifically includes: (i) band-structure engineering, (ii) nanostructuralization, (iii) surface O vacancy engineering, (iv) macro-/meso-/microporous structuralization, (v) exposed facet engineering, (vi) co-catalysts, (vii) the development of a Z-scheme system. The challenges and prospects for future development of this field are also present.

The photocatalytic activation of CO2 over mol. sieve-encapsulated cationic rhenium complex has been investigated under visible light (λ>350 nm). The cationic rhenium complex, [Re(I)(CO)3(bpy)(py)]+ (bpy=2,2-bipyridine, py=pyridine), has been encapsulated by ion-exchange method using the aq. soln. of [Re(I)(CO)3(bpy)(py)]+PF6- into the microporous NaY and the mesoporous AlMCM-41 mol. sieve acting as supramol. heterogeneous host. To confirm the encapsulation of [Re(I)(CO)3(bpy)(py)]+ into the pores of mol. sieve, Xe-NMR and FT-IR spectroscopies have been applied before and after the [Re(I)(CO)3(bpy)(py)]+ encapsulation. To investigate the photophys. and photochem. properties, mol. sieve-encapsulated cationic rhenium complex has been studied by UV-Visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV-DRS) with photoirradn. (λ>350 nm) at room temp. By monitoring the photoreaction of CO2 over the photocatalysts, the conversion of CO2 into CO and carbonate species has been obsd. by using in-situ FT-IR and time-resolved mass spectroscopy. From the exptl. results, the photocatalytic activation mechanism of CO2 on the catalyst under visible light (λ>350 nm) could be proposed via the photoinduced reaction of two electrons and two protons, resulting from water decompn.

As a promising approach to achieving two objectives with one strategy, photocatalytic CO2 conversion for C1/C2 "solar fuels" prodn. can provide a package soln. to the current global warming and growing energy demand by using inexhaustible solar energy and increasing atm. CO2. Although numerous efforts have been made to enhance the CO2 conversion efficiency through developing photocatalysts and CO2 redn. systems in recent years, some challenges still remain in improving the activity and selectivity of the CO2 photoredn. reactions. This review gives an overview of fundamental aspects and recent research advances of heterogeneous photocatalytic CO2 conversion systems in the last 3 years, and the catalysts are categorized as one-step excitation semiconductor systems, one-step excitation photosensitized semiconductor systems, and two-step excitation hybrid systems such as semiconductor heterojunction and Z-scheme systems. Also, some suggestions are given for further confirming that the carbon-contg. "solar fuels" are derived from CO2 rather than from the possible carbonaceous impurities in the photocatalytic system, because most of the papers cited in this review have not demonstrated that CO2 is the actual carbon source for photoredn. through 13CO2 labeling or other techniques. Lastly, a short perspective on the challenges and new directions in this field is proposed, which would be of great interest for the further improvements of activity and selectivity of the CO2 redn. reactions.

We demonstrate photocatalytic redn. of Methylene blue in the IR region, using PbSe/CdSe/CdS core/shell/shell heterostructure nanocrystals (HNCs) with type II or quasi-type II band offsets. Varying deposition rates of the CdS shell result in nanocrystals of diverse morphologies ranging from spheres to pyramids to tetrapods. The faceted shapes enable the selective growth of Au tips, which help increase photocatalytic activity since the Au tips serve as an electron sink. Comparative studies reveal that the photocatalytic activity appears to correlate with the integral overlap of electron and hole wave functions. Tetrapod-shaped HNCs with Au tips show considerably higher photocatalytic activity for the redn. of Methylene blue than sphere or pyramid-shaped HNCs of equiv. compn. arrangement.

Heterostructured ZnS-ZnO-CuS-CdS photocatalyst was synthesized via a sequential fabrication approach (ZnS→thermal treatment (ZnS-ZnO)→CuS formation (ZnS-ZnO-CuS)→CdS addn. (ZnS-ZnO-CuS-CdS)). Each component in this heterostructure has its own role for photocatalytic reaction. The oxide content controlled by thermal processing condition is a crucial factor for improving photocatalytic activity, and the CuS and CdS contents are controlled by their feedstocks. The effects of heterostructure compn. on the solar water splitting and org. dye decompn. were investigated under 1 sun irradn. (100 mW/cm2, AM 1.5G filter). The content optimized ZnS-ZnO-CuS-CdS photocatalyst produces 2452.7 μmol g-1 h-1 hydrogen, and it decomps. methyl blue much faster than the other cases. Thus, heterostructured photocatalysts can benefit the use of electrons and holes for improved photocatalytic activity.

A selective and efficient electrocatalyst for carbon dioxide reduction
Lu Qi; Rosen Jonathan; Zhou Yang; Hutchings Gregory S; Kimmel Yannick C; Jiao Feng; Chen Jingguang G

Converting carbon dioxide to useful chemicals in a selective and efficient manner remains a major challenge in renewable and sustainable energy research. Silver is an interesting electrocatalyst owing to its capability of converting carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide selectively at room temperature; however, the traditional polycrystalline silver electrocatalyst requires a large overpotential. Here we report a nanoporous silver electrocatalyst that is able to electrochemically reduce carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide with approximately 92% selectivity at a rate (that is, current) over 3,000 times higher than its polycrystalline counterpart under moderate overpotentials of <0.50 V. The high activity is a result of a large electrochemical surface area (approximately 150 times larger) and intrinsically high activity (approximately 20 times higher) compared with polycrystalline silver. The intrinsically higher activity may be due to the greater stabilization of CO2 (-) intermediates on the highly curved surface, resulting in smaller overpotentials needed to overcome the thermodynamic barrier.

Fuels and industrial chems. that are conventionally derived from fossil resources could potentially be produced in a renewable, sustainable manner by an electrochem. process that operates at room temp. and atm. pressure, using only water, CO2, and electricity as inputs. To enable this technol., improved catalysts must be developed. Herein, trends are reported in the electrocatalytic conversion of CO2 on a broad group of seven transition metal surfaces: Au, Ag, Zn, Cu, Ni, Pt, and Fe. Contrary to conventional knowledge in the field, all metals studied are capable of producing methane or methanol. Reaction rates are quantified for these two products and catalyst activity and selectivity are described in the framework of CO binding energies for the different metals. While selectivity toward methane or methanol is low for most of these metals, the fact that they are all capable of producing these products, even at a low rate, is important new knowledge. This study reveals a richer surface chem. for transition metals than previously known and provides new insights to guide the development of improved CO2 conversion catalysts.

Toward efficient CO2 electrocatalysis for CO prodn., nanostructured Au catalysts were extensively studied by the morphol. control of O plasma-induced Au islands, oxide-derived Au, Au nanowires (NWs), Au nanoparticles (NPs), nanoporous Au thin films, and Au needles, yet the better performance of one morphol. from another is presently not well-understood, making a rational design difficult. Here, the effects of metal morphologies were studied by focusing on Au NWs and NPs using d. functional theory calcns. Activity of two key undercoordinated active sites, namely, edge and corner sites, varies delicately with different local coordination environments of various NWs and NPs, and the obsd. activity trend is remarkably well-rationalized with a generalized coordination no. Also, it is identified that the type of planes and the dihedral angle of the constituent planes are two key factors detg. the catalytic activity. A general activity trend for CO2 redn. and H2 evolution with the consideration of the d. of each type of sites explains why Au NWs exhibit better catalytic performance than Au NPs, as in expts. From the theor. understandings, at.-level insights and design principles are provided toward efficiently catalyzing CO2 redn. using nanostructured metal catalysts.

Highly active and selective CO2 conversion into useful chems. is desirable to generate valuable products out of greenhouse gases. To date, various metal-based heterogeneous catalysts showed promising electrochem. catalytic activities for CO2 redn., yet there have been no systematic studies of the active sites of these metal catalysts that can guide further expts. The authors use 1st-principles calcns. to identify active sites for the CO2 redn. reaction for Ag and Au metals, the 2 metals that are the most active in producing CO. The authors compare the catalytic activity and selectivity of 3 reaction sites of nanoparticles, namely, low-index surfaces, edge sites, and corner sites of these metals. For nanoparticle corner sites, in particular, the size effect is crit., and 309-atom (or larger) nanoparticles should be used to appropriately describe realistic metal nanocatalysts. However, a 55-atom cluster model is often used in the literature to model nanoparticles. From a comparative study, the authors reveal that corner sites are the most active for the CO2 redn. reaction in the case of Au, whereas edge sites are the most active in the case of Ag. Although Au is generally the more active CO2 redn. catalyst than Ag due to the intrinsically stronger binding of *C-species, reducing the size of Au nanoparticles up to 2 nm also increases the unwanted H2 evolution reaction, as obsd. in a recent expt. However, reducing the size of Au nanoparticles up to 2 nm enhances the unwanted H2 evolution reaction, as obsd. in a recent expt., although reducing the size of Ag nanoparticles up to 2 nm enhances the CO2 redn. reaction without suffering from the H2 evolution reaction, and on this basis, Ag nanoparticles are a comparable or even better-performing, inexpensive catalyst than Au for electrochem. CO prodn. Probably the catalyst design principle (elemental compn., morphol., and size) is metal-dependent and should be carefully tailored for each system.

The electrochem. CO2 redn. reaction to form valued hydrocarbon mols. is an attractive process, because it can be coupled with renewable energy resources for C recycling. For an efficient CO2 conversion, designing a catalyst with high activity and selectivity is crucial, because the CO2 redn. reaction in aq. media competes with the H evolution reaction (HER) intensely. The authors have developed a strategy to tune CO2 redn. activity by modulating the binding energies of the intermediates on the electrocatalyst surfaces with the assistance of mols. that contain the functional group. The amine functional group on Ag nanoparticle is highly effective in improving selective CO prodn. (faradaic efficiency to 94.2%) by selectively suppressing HER, while the thiol group rather increases HER activity. A d. functional theory (DFT) calcn. supports the theory that attaching amine mols. to Ag nanoparticles destabilizes the H binding, which effectively suppresses HER selectively, while an opposite tendency is found with thiol mols. Changes in the product selectivity, depending on the functional group, are also obsd. when the org. mols. are added after nanoparticle synthesis or nanoparticles are immobilized with an amine (or thiol)-contg. anchoring agent. CO faradaic efficiencies were consistently improved when the Ag nanoparticle was modified with amine groups, compared with that of its thiol counterpart.

The incorporation of Cu species in TiO2 photocatalysts is crit. in photocatalytic CO2 redn. to fuels, but the effect of Cu valence is poorly understood. In this work, Cu/TiO2 (P25) nanoparticle catalysts were prepd. by a simple pptn. and calcination method. The as-prepd. Cu/TiO2 sample was dominated by Cu2+ species. Thermal pretreatment of the as-prepd. samples in He and H2 atmosphere resulted in the transition to a surface dominated by Cu+ and mixed Cu+/Cu0, resp., confirmed by in situ XPS and diffuse-reflectance IR Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) analyses. These thermal pretreatments in reducing atmospheres also induced the formation of defect sites such as oxygen vacancies and Ti3+. The various Cu/TiO2 catalysts were tested in CO2 photoredn. with water vapor under simulated solar irradn., and their activities were in the order of as-prepd. (unpretreated) < He-pretreated < H2-pretreated. Compared with unpretreated TiO2 (P25), the H2-pretreated Cu/TiO2 demonstrated a 10-fold and 189-fold enhancement in the prodn. of CO and CH4, resp. This significant enhancement was mainly attributed to the synergy of the following two factors: (1) the formation of surface defect sites promoting CO2 adsorption and subsequent charge transfer to the adsorbed CO2; (2) the existence of Cu+/Cu0 couples that facilitate electron and hole trapping at different sites.

Photoredn. of CO2 to hydrocarbons is a sustainable energy technol. which not only mitigates emissions but also provides alternative fuels. However, one of the largest challenges is to increase the overall CO2 photo-conversion efficiency when water is used as the reducing reagent. Mesoporous silica supported Cu/TiO2 nanocomposites were synthesized through a one-pot sol-gel method, and the photoredn. expts. were carried out in a continuous-flow reactor using CO2 and water vapor as the reactants under the irradn. of a Xe lamp. The high surface area mesoporous silica substrate ( > 300 m2/g) greatly enhanced CO2 photoredn., possibly due to improved TiO2 dispersion and increased adsorption of CO2 and H2O on the catalyst. CO is the primary product of CO2 redn. for TiO2-SiO2 catalysts without Cu. The addn. of Cu species, which was identified to be Cu2O by the XPS, markedly increased the overall CO2 conversion efficiency as well as the selectivity to CH4, by suppressing the electron-hole recombination and enhancing multi-electron reactions. A synergistic effect was obsd. by combining the porous SiO2 support and the deposition of Cu on TiO2. The peak prodn. rates of CO and CH4 reached 60 and 10 μmol g-cat-1 h-1, resp., for the 0.5%Cu/TiO2-SiO2 composite that has the optimum Cu concn.; the peak quantum yield is 1.41%. Deactivation and regeneration of the catalyst was obsd. and the mechanism was discussed. Desorption of the reaction intermediates from the active sites may be the rate limiting step.

A new manganese-vanadate hybrid structure, Mn(H2O)(bpy)V2O6 (I; bpy = 2,2'-bipyridine), was synthesized via hydrothermal methods and characterized by single crystal x-ray diffraction [P21/n, Z = 4, a 6.8557(4), b 10.4900(6), c 19.7921(13) Å, β 96.419(4)°], IR spectroscopy, TGA, magnetic susceptibility measurements, and UV-visible diffuse reflectance. The structure is comprised of manganese vanadate layers with 2,2'-bipyridine ligands coordinated to the Mn(II) cations. The H2O mols. coordinated to the Mn sites can be reversibly desorbed at ∼190° with the formation of a new hybrid structure before then further decompg. to MnV2O6 upon heating to 300°. Notably, I undergoes a reversible structural transformation to Mn(bpy)V4O11(bpy) (II) under hydrothermal conditions. This structural transformation results from addnl. bpy-ligand coordination to 1/4 of the V sites. Magnetic data indicate Mn(II) cations in both I and II are high spin (S = 5/2). The optical bandgap sizes of I and II are ∼2.2 eV and ∼1.6 eV, resp., and are calcd. by DFT methods to arise primarily from Mn-to-bpy and Mn-to-V electronic transitions between the valence and conduction bands. Visible-light irradn. of II in aq. solns. leads to photocatalytic activities for total H2O splitting at rates of ∼92 μmol H2/1/2O2 g-1 h-1 and ∼21 μmol H2/1/2O2 g-1 h-1 for II, with and without a 1% Pt surface cocatalyst, resp., but no measurable activity for I. Rates for only H2 prodn. using aq. MeOH solns. were significantly lower. Results from electronic structure calcns. show that the change in ligand coordination from I to II causes the excited electrons to populate slightly lower-energy bpy ligand π* orbitals that are coordinated to V(V), and thus this structural change in II leads to a better excited-state charge sepn. within its hybrid structure.

The activation of CO2 on defective surface of Cu(I)/TiO2-x was studied using in situ diffuse reflectance IR Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). CO2- species, generated upon an electron attachment to CO2, are spontaneously dissocd. into CO even in the dark on a partially oxygen depleted Cu(I)/TiO2-x surface prepd. by thermal annealing in an inert environment. The formation of CO bound on Cu+ sites was identified in the DRIFT spectra, and isotopic C-labeling expts. confirmed that the produced CO was derived from CO2. The spontaneous dissocn. of CO2- in the dark is to a large extent assocd. with the surface oxygen vacancies that provide not only the electronic charge (i.e., formation of Ti3+) but also the sites for the adsorption of oxygen atoms from CO2. The surface Cu+ species may facilitate destabilizing adsorbed CO2- and enhance its subsequent dissocn. to CO. The defective surface is much more active than defect-free surface; the healed oxygen vacancies after CO2 redn. can be easily regenerated via inert gas annealing at a moderate temp. (i.e., 300°). Compared with in the dark, CO2 activation and dissocn. under photoillumination is remarkably improved, possibly because of sustained electron supply and partial regeneration of surface oxygen vacancy induced by irradn. The results from DRIFTS anal. were verified by the measurement of catalytic activity using gas chromatog. These findings are important to advancing the understanding in the chem. of CO2 adsorption and photocatalytic redn. on the surface of metal oxide catalysts.

Liu, Lianjun; Zhao, Huilei; Andino, Jean M.; Li, Ying

CO2 photoredn. with water vapor has been studied on three TiO2 nanocrystal polymorphs (anatase, rutile, and brookite) that were engineered with defect-free and oxygen-deficient surfaces, resp. It was demonstrated that helium pretreatment of the as-prepd. TiO2 at a moderate temp. resulted in the creation of surface oxygen vacancies (VO) and Ti3+ sites on anatase and brookite but not on rutile. The prodn. of CO and CH4 from CO2 photoredn. was remarkably enhanced on defective anatase and brookite TiO2 (up to 10-fold enhancement) as compared to the defect-free surfaces. Defective brookite was photocatalytically more active than anatase and rutile, probably because of a lower formation energy of VO on brookite. The results from in situ diffuse reflectance IR Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) analyses suggested that (1) defect-free TiO2 was not active for CO2 photoredn. since no CO2- is generated, and (2) CO2 photoredn. to CO possibly underwent different reaction pathways on oxygen-deficient anatase and brookite via different intermediates (e.g., CO2- on anatase; CO2- and HCOOH on brookite). The combined DRIFTS and photoactivity studies reported in this paper have provided new insights to the role of surface defects in CO2 photoredn. on TiO2 nanocrystals, and revealed significant information on the much less studied but promising brookite phase.

Cu/TiO2 composites are extensively studied for photocatalytic redn. of CO2 with H2O, but the roles of Cu species (Cu2+, Cu+, or Cu0) is not well understood, and the photocatalyst deactivation mechanism is seldom addressed. X-ray absorption spectra and diffuse reflectance IR spectra are used to explore the surface chem. of Cu/TiO2 composites under CO2 photoredn. environment. The air-calcined Cu/TiO2 (Cu/Ti(air)) surface was dominated by isolated Cu2+ sites, while the one post-treated with H2 at 200 °C (Cu/Ti(H2)) was rich in Cu+ and oxygen vacancy (VO). Cu/Ti(H2) showed more than 50% higher activity than Cu/Ti(air) for CO2 photoredn. to CO, mainly resulting from the synergy of Cu+, OH groups, and VO that could scavenge holes to enhance electron transfer, provide CO2 adsorption sites, and facilitate the activation and conversion of the adsorbed CO2 (HCO3- and CO2-). Meanwhile, the consumption of OH groups and Cu+ active sites by holes may result in the deactivation of Cu/Ti(H2). Moreover, in situ XAS results directly demonstrated that (1) the photoinduced oxidn. of Cu+ to Cu2+ changed the surrounding environments of Cu by increasing the coordination no.; (2) thermal treatment by H2 could not fully recover the OH and Cu+ sites to their original states; and (3) adding hole scavengers (e.g., methanol) maintained or even increased the more active Cu+ species from the photoredn. of Cu2+, thus leading to a higher and more stable CO2 redn. activity.

In Situ FT-IR Spectroscopic Study of CO2 and CO Adsorption on Y2O3, ZrO2, and Yttria-Stabilized ZrO2
Kock Eva-Maria; Kogler Michaela; Bielz Thomas; Klotzer Bernhard; Penner Simon
The journal of physical chemistry. C, Nanomaterials and interfaces

In situ FT-IR spectroscopy was exploited to study the adsorption of CO2 and CO on commercially available yttria-stabilized ZrO2 (8 mol % Y, YSZ-8), Y2O3, and ZrO2. All three oxides were pretreated at high temperatures (1173 K) in air, which leads to effective dehydroxylation of pure ZrO2. Both Y2O3 and YSZ-8 show a much higher reactivity toward CO and CO2 adsorption than ZrO2 because of more facile rehydroxylation of Y-containing phases. Several different carbonate species have been observed following CO2 adsorption on Y2O3 and YSZ-8, which are much more strongly bound on the former, due to formation of higher-coordinated polydentate carbonate species upon annealing. As the crucial factor governing the formation of carbonates, the presence of reactive (basic) surface hydroxyl groups on Y-centers was identified. Therefore, chemisorption of CO2 most likely includes insertion of the CO2 molecule into a reactive surface hydroxyl group and the subsequent formation of a bicarbonate species. Formate formation following CO adsorption has been observed on all three oxides but is less pronounced on ZrO2 due to effective dehydroxylation of the surface during high-temperature treatment. The latter generally causes suppression of the surface reactivity of ZrO2 samples regarding reactions involving CO or CO2 as reaction intermediates.

van Duin, Adri C. T.; Bryantsev, Vyacheslav S.; Diallo, Mamadou S.; Goddard, William A.; Rahaman, Obaidur; Doren, Douglas J.; Raymand, David; Hermansson, Kersti

To enable large-scale reactive dynamic simulations of copper oxide/water and copper ion/water interactions we have extended the ReaxFF reactive force field framework to Cu/O/H interactions. To this end, we employed a multistage force field development strategy, where the initial training set (contg. metal/metal oxide/metal hydroxide condensed phase data and [Cu(H2O)n]2+ cluster structures and energies) is augmented by single-point quantum mechanices (QM) energies from [Cu(H2O)n]2+ clusters abstracted from a ReaxFF mol. dynamics simulation. This provides a convenient strategy to both enrich the training set and to validate the final force field. To further validate the force field description we performed mol. dynamics simulations on Cu2+/water systems. We found good agreement between our results and earlier exptl. and QM-based mol. dynamics work for the av. Cu/water coordination, Jahn-Teller distortion, and inversion in [Cu(H2O)6]2+ clusters and first- and second-shell O-Cu-O angular distributions, indicating that this force field gives a satisfactory description of the Cu-cation/water interactions. We believe that this force field provides a computationally convenient method for studying the soln. and surface chem. of metal cations and metal oxides and, as such, has applications for studying protein/metal cation complexes, pH-dependent crystal growth/dissoln., and surface catalysis.

CO2 conversion is an essential technol. to develop a sustainable carbon economy for the present and the future. Many studies have focused extensively on the electrochem. conversion of CO2 into various useful chems. However, there is not yet a soln. of sufficiently high enough efficiency and stability to demonstrate practical applicability. In this work, we use first-principles-based high-throughput screening to propose silver-based catalysts for efficient electrochem. redn. of CO2 to CO, while decreasing the overpotential by 0.4-0.5 V. We discovered the covalency-aided electrochem. reaction (CAER) mechanism in which p-block dopants have a major effect on the modulating reaction energetics by imposing partial covalency into the metal catalysts, thereby enhancing their catalytic activity well beyond modulations arising from d-block dopants. In particular, sulfur or arsenic doping can effectively minimize the overpotential with good structural and electrochem. stability. We expect this work to provide useful insights to guide the development of a feasible strategy to overcome the limitations of current technol. for electrochem. CO2 conversion.

Jaguar: A high-performance quantum chemistry software program with strengths in life and materials sciences
Bochevarov, Art D.; Harder, Edward; Hughes, Thomas F.; Greenwood, Jeremy R.; Braden, Dale A.; Philipp, Dean M.; Rinaldo, David; Halls, Mathew D.; Zhang, Jing; Friesner, Richard A.

A review. Jaguar is an ab initio quantum chem. program that specializes in fast electronic structure predictions for mol. systems of medium and large size. Jaguar focuses on computational methods with reasonable computational scaling with the size of the system, such as d. functional theory (DFT) and local second-order Moller-Plesset perturbation theory. The favorable scaling of the methods and the high efficiency of the program make it possible to conduct routine computations involving several thousand MOs. This performance is achieved through a utilization of the pseudospectral approxn. and several levels of parallelization. The speed advantages are beneficial for applying Jaguar in biomol. computational modeling. Addnl., owing to its superior wave function guess for transition-metal-contg. systems, Jaguar finds applications in inorg. and bioinorg. chem. The emphasis on larger systems and transition metal elements paves the way toward developing Jaguar for its use in materials science modeling. The article describes the historical and new features of Jaguar, such as improved parallelization of many modules, innovations in ab initio pKa prediction, and new semiempirical corrections for nondynamic correlation errors in DFT. Jaguar applications in drug discovery, materials science, force field parameterization, and other areas of computational research are reviewed. Timing benchmarks and other results obtained from the most recent Jaguar code are provided. The article concludes with a discussion of challenges and directions for future development of the program. © 2013 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.

Montmorillonite (MMT) modified TiO2 nanocomposites were synthesized by single step sol-gel method. The samples were characterized by XRD, FE-SEM, HR-TEM, FTIR spectra, N2-adsorption-desorption, UV-visible and photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy. Modification of TiO2 with MMT controlled the crystal growth and produced anatase phase of delaminated TiO2 pillared montmorillonite. The size of TiO2 nanoparticles reduced from 18.73 to 13.87 nm after adding MMT, while the surface area and pore vol. increased. The UV-visible results identified blue shift in TiO2 band gap for the MMT modified samples. In addn., PL spectroscopy revealed significant inhibition in recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs. The performance of MMT modified TiO2 samples for reducing CO2 with H2O to hydrocarbon fuels was investigated. The effects of parameters such as MMT loading on TiO2, H2O/CO2 feed ratios, and reaction temp. on TiO2 photocatalytic activity was studied. Loading MMT on TiO2 enhanced the performance of TiO2 and markedly increased CO2 redn. to C1-C3 hydrocarbon fuels. The highest yield rates produced were 441.5 and 103 μmol g cat-1 h-1 for CH4 and CO, resp. under UV light irradiations at 20 wt.% MMT loading, reactor pressure of 0.20 bars and 393 K reaction temp. These results revealed silicate layers of MMT dispersed in the given TiO2 sol system and vacant d-orbits of the MMT transition metal ions have obvious effect on the photocatalytic activity of TiO2. The possible pathways and reaction mechanisms of CH4 and CO productions were also suggested. Thus, MMT is a potentially attractive material to improve TiO2 as a photocatalyst for application in photocatalytic CO2 redn.

Insights into the TiO2-based photocatalytic systems and their mechanisms

Photocatalysis is a multifunctional phenomenon that can be employed for energy applications such as H2 prodn., CO2 redn. into fuels, and environmental applications such as pollutant degrdns., antibacterial disinfection, etc. In this direction, it is not an exaggerated fact that TiO2 is blooming in the field of photocatalysis, which is largely explored for various photocatalytic applications. The deeper understanding of TiO2 photocatalysis has led to the design of new photocatalytic materials with multiple functionalities. Accordingly, this paper exclusively reviews the recent developments in the modification of TiO2 photocatalyst towards the understanding of its photocatalytic mechanisms. These modifications generally involve the phys. and chem. changes in TiO2 such as anisotropic structuring and integration with other metal oxides, plasmonic materials, carbon-based materials, etc. Such modifications essentially lead to the changes in the energy structure of TiO2 that largely boosts up the photocatalytic process via enhancing the band structure alignments, visible light absorption, carrier sepn., and transportation in the system. For instance, the ability to align the band structure in TiO2 makes it suitable for multiple photocatalytic processes such as degrdn. of various pollutants, H2 prodn., CO2 conversion, etc. For these reasons, TiO2 can be realized as a prototypical photocatalyst, which paves ways to develop new photocatalytic materials in the field. In this context, this review paper sheds light into the emerging trends in TiO2 in terms of its modifications towards multifunctional photocatalytic applications.

The development of artificial photosynthesis aims to solve the increasing energy demand and assocd. environmental problems. A model photosynthetic system employing a composite of semiconductors with a Z-scheme can potentially mimic the combined power of photosystems 1 and 2 to transfer electrons. In this work, octahedral cuprous oxide covered with titanium dioxide nanoparticles (Cu2O/TiO2) are synthesized by a solvothermal strategy that provides high morphol. and crystallog. control. The formation of a p-n heterojunction and characterization of the Type II band alignment of the composite are performed by diffuse reflectance UV-visible (DRUV) spectroscopy, UPS (UPS), and XPS. Upon UV-visible irradn. (λ ≥ 305 nm) of the composite in the presence of water vapor as the hole scavenger, the photoredn. of CO2(g) proceeds selectively to generate CO(g). The prodn. rate of CO by the composite, Rco = 2.11 μmol g-1cat h-1, is 4-times larger than for pure Cu2O under identical conditions. Contrasting XPS analyses of Cu2O and Cu2O/TiO2, during photocatalysts operation and the detection of photogenerated hydroxyl radicals (HO·) in the heterostructure at variance with the results obtained for pure Cu2O are taken as evidences that TiO2 protects Cu2O from undergoing photocorrosion. These results provide direct evidence of an efficient Z-scheme as the main mechanism for harvesting energy during CO2 redn. in the synthesized materials.

Adsorption of CO2 on solid natural amino acids (AAs) D-arginine, bis(2-hydroxypropyl)amine, cysteamine, L-leucine, D-serine, L-valine, sarcosine, and taurine has been studied in the temp. range of 303-423 K. In a temp. programmed thermal reactor, CO2 adsorption was carried out in an isothermally controlled flow of CO2 and the adsorbed CO2 was desorbed by shifting temp. to 523 K. Based on the exptl. results, the amino acid taurine (TAU) was found to adsorb the highest quantity of CO2 (3.7 mmol g-1) among the studied AAs which was two-fold higher than the quantity of CO2 absorbed by activated carbon at 303 K. Theor. calcns. have agreed with the exptl. results and have revealed that the interaction between the AAs and CO2 is non-covalent in nature. The polar side chains of AAs are responsible for their high binding ability with CO2. AAs with heteroatoms such as sulfur has great potential as ligands in developing selective adsorbents for CO2 capture.

A review. Size- and morphol.-controlled catalytic colloidal nanoparticles are emerging as novel catalysts for heterogeneous catalysis, but capping ligands adsorbed on the nanoparticle surfaces inherited from the colloidal synthesis always stand as a problem. This perspective highlights recent progress on the influences and removal of capping ligands on catalytic colloidal nanoparticles. Depending on the system, capping ligands can act as either a poison or a promoter for the capped nanoparticles and the underlying mechanisms will be discussed. Various methods for the removal of capping ligands on catalytic colloidal nanoparticles are summarized with an emphasis on a novel controlled oxidn. treatment that we recently developed.

The mechanism of photocatalytic conversion of CO2 and H2O over copper oxide promoted titania, Cu(I)/TiO2, was investigated by means of in situ DRIFT spectroscopy in combination with isotopically labeled 13CO2. In addn. to small amts. of 13CO, 12CO was demonstrated to be the primary product of the reaction by the 2115 cm-1 Cu(I)-CO signature, indicating that carbon residues on the catalyst surface are involved in reactions with predominantly photocatalytically activated surface adsorbed water. This was confirmed by prolonged exposure of the catalyst to light and water vapor, which significantly reduced the amt. of CO formed in a subsequent expt. in the DRIFT cell. In addn., formation of carboxylates and (bi)carbonates was obsd. by exposure of the Cu(I)/TiO2 surface to CO2 in the dark. These carboxylates and (bi)carbonates decomp. upon light irradn., yielding predominantly CO2. At the same time a novel carbonate species is produced (having a main absorption at ∼1395 cm-1) by adsorption of photocatalytically produced CO on the Cu(I)/TiO2 surface, most likely through a reverse Boudouard reaction of photocatalytically activated CO2 with carbon residues. The finding that carbon residues are involved in photocatalytic water activation and CO2 redn. might have important implications for the rates of artificial photosynthesis reported in many studies in the literature, in particular those using photoactive materials synthesized with carbon contg. precursors.

Large amts. of anthropogenic CO2 emissions assocd. with increased fossil fuel consumption have led to global warming and an energy crisis. The photocatalytic redn. of CO2 into solar fuels such as methane or methanol is believed to be one of the best methods to address these two problems. In addn. to light harvesting and charge sepn., the adsorption/activation and redn. of CO2 on the surface of heterogeneous catalysts remain a scientifically crit. challenge, which greatly limits the overall photoconversion efficiency and selectivity of CO2 redn. This review describes recent advances in the fundamental understanding of CO2 photoredn. on the surface of heterogeneous catalysts and particularly provides an overview of enhancing the adsorption/activation of CO2 mols. The reaction mechanism and pathways of CO2 redn. as well as their dependent factors are also analyzed and discussed, which is expected to enable an increase in the overall efficiency of CO2 redn. through minimizing the reaction barriers and controlling the selectivity towards the desired products. The challenges and perspectives of CO2 photoredn. over heterogeneous catalysts are presented as well.

Com. P25 modified by Au-Cu alloy nanoparticles as thin film exhibits, for CO2 redn. by water under sun simulated light, a rate of methane prodn. above 2000 μmol (g of photocatalyst)-1 h-1. Although evolution of hydrogen is obsd. and O2 and ethane detected, the selectivity of conduction band electrons for methane formation is almost complete, about 97%. This photocatalytic behavior is completely different from that measured for Au/P25 (hydrogen evolution) and Cu/P25 (lower activity, but similar methane selectivity). Characterization by TEM, XPS, and UV-vis spectroscopy shows that Au and Cu are alloyed in the nanoparticles. FT-IR spectroscopy and chem. anal. have allowed one to detect on the photocatalyst surface the presence of CO2•-, Cu-CO, and elemental C. Accordingly, a mechanism in which the role of Au is to respond under visible light and Cu binds to CO and directs the redn. pathway is proposed.

Resolving surface chemical states in XPS analysis of first row transition metals, oxides and hydroxides: Sc, Ti, V, Cu and Zn
Biesinger, Mark C.; Lau, Leo W. M.; Gerson, Andrea R.; Smart, Roger St. C.
Applied Surface Science
(

Chem. state x-ray photoelectron spectroscopic anal. of 1st row transition metals and their oxides and hydroxides is challenging due to the complexity of the 2p spectra resulting from peak asymmetries, complex multiplet splitting, shake-up and plasmon loss structure, and uncertain, overlapping binding energies. Current literature shows that all values necessary for reproducible, quant. chem. state anal. are usually not provided. A more consistent, practical and effective approach to curve-fitting the various chem. states in a variety of Sc, Ti, V, Cu and Zn metals, oxides and hydroxides is reported. The curve-fitting procedures proposed are based on a combination of (1) std. spectra from quality ref. samples, (2) a survey of appropriate literature databases and/or a compilation of the literature refs., and (3) specific literature refs. where fitting procedures are available. Binding energies, full-width at half max. (FWHM) values, spin-orbit splitting values, asym. peak-shape fitting parameters, and, for Cu and Zn, Auger parameters values are presented. The quantification procedure for Cu species details the use of the shake-up satellites for Cu(II)-contg. compds. and the exact binding energies of the Cu(0) and Cu(I) peaks. The use of the modified Auger parameter for Cu and Zn species allows for corroborating evidence when there is uncertainty in the binding energy assignment. These procedures can remove uncertainties in anal. of surface states in nano-particles, corrosion, catalysis and surface-engineered materials.

A review. Two major energy-related problems confront the world in the next 50 years. First, increased worldwide competition for gradually depleting fossil fuel reserves (derived from past photosynthesis) will lead to higher costs, both monetarily and politically. Second, atm. CO2 levels are at their highest recorded level since records began. Further increases are predicted to produce large and uncontrollable impacts on the world climate. These projected impacts extend beyond climate to ocean acidification, because the ocean is a major sink for atm. CO2. Providing a future energy supply that is secure and CO2-neutral will require switching to non-fossil energy sources such as wind, solar, nuclear, and geothermal energy and developing methods for transforming the energy produced by these new sources into forms that can be stored,transported, and used upon demand. This Review describes the results of a workshop held to explore these concepts in regard to the development of new and more efficient catalytic processes for the conversion of CO2 to a variety of carbon-based fuels.

A review. Photocatalytic conversion of CO2 to either a renewable fuel or valuable chems., using solar energy has attracted more and more attention, due to the great potential to provide an alternative clean fuel and solve the problems related to the global warming. This review covers the current progress of photocatalytic conversion of CO2 by photocatalysis over the metal oxides. A brief overview of the fundamental aspects for artificial photosynthesis has been given and the development of novel photocatalysts for CO2 photoredn. has been discussed. Several key factors for high-efficiency CO2 photoredn. and the recent development of photocatalytic reactor design for this artificial photosynthesis have also been highlighted.

A review. Photocatalytic redn. of CO2 into hydrocarbon fuels, an artificial photosynthesis, is based on the simulation of natural photosynthesis in green plants, whereby O2 and carbohydrates are produced from H2O and CO2 using sunlight as an energy source. It couples the reductive half-reaction of CO2 fixation with a matched oxidative half-reaction such as H2O oxidn., to achieve a C neutral cycle, which is like killing 2 birds with one stone in terms of saving the environment and supplying future energy. The present review provides an overview and highlights recent state-of-the-art accomplishments of overcoming the drawback of low photoconversion efficiency and selectivity through the design of highly active photocatalysts from the point of adsorption of reactants, charge sepn. and transport, light harvesting, and CO2 activation. It specifically includes: (i) band-structure engineering, (ii) nanostructuralization, (iii) surface O vacancy engineering, (iv) macro-/meso-/microporous structuralization, (v) exposed facet engineering, (vi) co-catalysts, (vii) the development of a Z-scheme system. The challenges and prospects for future development of this field are also present.

The cationic rhenium complex, [Re(I)(CO)3(bpy)(py)]+ (bpy=2,2-bipyridine, py=pyridine), has been encapsulated by ion-exchange method using the aq. soln. of [Re(I)(CO)3(bpy)(py)]+PF6- into the microporous NaY and the mesoporous AlMCM-41 mol. sieve acting as supramol. heterogeneous host. As a promising approach to achieving two objectives with one strategy, photocatalytic CO2 conversion for C1/C2 "solar fuels" prodn. can provide a package soln. to the current global warming and growing energy demand by using inexhaustible solar energy and increasing atm. CO2. Although numerous efforts have been made to enhance the CO2 conversion efficiency through developing photocatalysts and CO2 redn. systems in recent years, some challenges still remain in improving the activity and selectivity of the CO2 photoredn. reactions. This review gives an overview of fundamental aspects and recent research advances of heterogeneous photocatalytic CO2 conversion systems in the last 3 years, and the catalysts are categorized as one-step excitation semiconductor systems, one-step excitation photosensitized semiconductor systems, and two-step excitation hybrid systems such as semiconductor heterojunction and Z-scheme systems. Also, some suggestions are given for further confirming that the carbon-contg. "solar fuels" are derived from CO2 rather than from the possible carbonaceous impurities in the photocatalytic system, because most of the papers cited in this review have not demonstrated that CO2 is the actual carbon source for photoredn. through 13CO2 labeling or other techniques. Lastly, a short perspective on the challenges and new directions in this field is proposed, which would be of great interest for the further improvements of activity and selectivity of the CO2 redn. reactions.

We demonstrate photocatalytic redn. of Methylene blue in the IR region, using PbSe/CdSe/CdS core/shell/shell heterostructure nanocrystals (HNCs) with type II or quasi-type II band offsets. Varying deposition rates of the CdS shell result in nanocrystals of diverse morphologies ranging from spheres to pyramids to tetrapods. A selective and efficient electrocatalyst for carbon dioxide reduction
Lu Qi; Rosen Jonathan; Zhou Yang; Hutchings Gregory S; Kimmel Yannick C; Jiao Feng; Chen Jingguang G
Nature communications

.
Converting carbon dioxide to useful chemicals in a selective and efficient manner remains a major challenge in renewable and sustainable energy research. Silver is an interesting electrocatalyst owing to its capability of converting carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide selectively at room temperature; however, the traditional polycrystalline silver electrocatalyst requires a large overpotential. Here we report a nanoporous silver electrocatalyst that is able to electrochemically reduce carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide with approximately 92% selectivity at a rate (that is, current) over 3,000 times higher than its polycrystalline counterpart under moderate overpotentials of <0.50 V. The high activity is a result of a large electrochemical surface area (approximately 150 times larger) and intrinsically high activity (approximately 20 times higher) compared with polycrystalline silver. The intrinsically higher activity may be due to the greater stabilization of CO2 (-) intermediates on the highly curved surface, resulting in smaller overpotentials needed to overcome the thermodynamic barrier.

Fuels and industrial chems. that are conventionally derived from fossil resources could potentially be produced in a renewable, sustainable manner by an electrochem. process that operates at room temp. and atm. pressure, using only water, CO2, and electricity as inputs. To enable this technol., improved catalysts must be developed. Herein, trends are reported in the electrocatalytic conversion of CO2 on a broad group of seven transition metal surfaces: Au, Ag, Zn, Cu, Ni, Pt, and Fe. Contrary to conventional knowledge in the field, all metals studied are capable of producing methane or methanol. Reaction rates are quantified for these two products and catalyst activity and selectivity are described in the framework of CO binding energies for the different metals. While selectivity toward methane or methanol is low for most of these metals, the fact that they are all capable of producing these products, even at a low rate, is important new knowledge. This study reveals a richer surface chem. for transition metals than previously known and provides new insights to guide the development of improved CO2 conversion catalysts.

Highly active and selective CO2 conversion into useful chems. is desirable to generate valuable products out of greenhouse gases. To date, various metal-based heterogeneous catalysts showed promising electrochem. catalytic activities for CO2 redn., yet there have been no systematic studies of the active sites of these metal catalysts that can guide further expts. The authors use 1st-principles calcns. to identify active sites for the CO2 redn. reaction for Ag and Au metals, the 2 metals that are the most active in producing CO. The authors compare the catalytic activity and selectivity of 3 reaction sites of nanoparticles, namely, low-index surfaces, edge sites, and corner sites of these metals. For nanoparticle corner sites, in particular, the size effect is crit., and 309-atom (or larger) nanoparticles should be used to appropriately describe realistic metal nanocatalysts. However, a 55-atom cluster model is often used in the literature to model nanoparticles. From a comparative study, the authors reveal that corner sites are the most active for the CO2 redn. reaction in the case of Au, whereas edge sites are the most active in the case of Ag. Although Au is generally the more active CO2 redn. catalyst than Ag due to the intrinsically stronger binding of *C-species, reducing the size of Au nanoparticles up to 2 nm also increases the unwanted H2 evolution reaction, as obsd. in a recent expt. However, reducing the size of Au nanoparticles up to 2 nm enhances the unwanted H2 evolution reaction, as obsd. in a recent expt., although reducing the size of Ag nanoparticles up to 2 nm enhances the CO2 redn. reaction without suffering from the H2 evolution reaction, and on this basis, Ag nanoparticles are a comparable or even better-performing, inexpensive catalyst than Au for electrochem. CO prodn. Probably the catalyst design principle (elemental compn., morphol., and size) is metal-dependent and should be carefully tailored for each system.
